questions.text: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Moraxella species, a type of gram-negative diplobacilli, are involved in causing angular conjunctivitis which is a type of chronic conjunctivitis.

Angular conjunctivitis is a chronic type of conjunctivitis where there is inflammation of the conjunctiva at the lid margins and the inner and outer canthi of the eyes with red, scaly, excoriated, macerated and fissured skin at the canthi. This is because of the proteolytic enzymes secreted by the Moraxella species.

Patients with angular conjunctivitis usually experience eye irritation, a burning sensation and collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles. These patients can also have associated blepharitis and papillary and follicular conjunctivitis.

Causative organisms are Moraxella lacunata, Moraxella axenfeld and Staphylococcus aureus (Rare cause). The source of infection is typically the nasal tract or the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eyes through contaminated hands or handkerchiefs. Treatment includes oxytetracycline 1% ointment for 10 to 14 days, and zinc oxide as it inhibits proteolytic enzymes.

The image given below shows the eye of a patient infected with angular conjunctivitis.

Other options: 

Option B: Haemophilus influenzae causes acute conjunctivitis.

Option C: Adenovirus is the most common cause of viral conjunctivitis and it most commonly causes follicular conjunctivitis, pharyngoconjunctival fever, and epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

Option D: Coxsackie B virus is known to cause aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, pericarditis, and myocarditis. There are no known mentions of ocular disease caused by the virus.

Note: Pathogens that cause bacterial conjunctivitis

Hyperacute (symptoms develop within 24 hours; aggressive course) Acute (resolving in less than 4 weeks)  Chronic (of greater than 4 weeks duration)
Neisseria gonorrhoeae Staphylococcus aureus Staphylococcus aureus
Neisseria meningitidis Streptococcus pneumoniae Moraxella lacunata
  Haemophilus influenzae Enteric bacteria

Follicular Conjunctivitis

Adenovirus serotypes 1-11 and 19

Pharyngoconjunctival Fever

questions.text: While browsing through the news channels, Geeta came across a panel discussion on public health diseases celebrating the elimination of a peculiar condition of the eye. It was known as the most important cause of corneal blindness in India and shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given sago-grain appearance of the conjunctiva is seen in trachoma. It was the most important cause of corneal blindness in India affecting young children. 

Conjunctival appearance:

1. In trachoma

  • Sago-grain appearance
  • A follicular reaction 

2. In vernal keratoconjunctivitis

  • Cobblestone appearance
  • A papillary reaction seen in palpebral conjunctiva

3. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis

  • White-pinkish nodule in the bulbar conjunctiva

4. Xerophthalmia

  • Epithelial xerosis
  • Bitot spot in bulbar conjunctiva

On December 08, 2017, Shri J P Nadda, Union Minister of Health and Family Welfare at that time, released the National Trachoma Survey Report and declared that India is now free from 'infective trachoma'.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice under the SAFE strategy for trachoma management?
questions.solution:
Oral azithromycin is the drug of choice in the SAFE strategy of trachoma management. The adult dose is 1 g while 20 mg/kg body weight is given for children.

Oral azithromycin is slowly replacing tetracycline eye ointment as the first line drug used in trachoma treatment. The experience of Morocco, the first country that used azithromycin in a large-scale, nationwide elimination programme, has paved the way for the worldwide application of azithromycin as part of the SAFE strategy. 

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. Which of the following condition commonly causes this?
questions.solution:
Irritation in the eye associated with areas of scleral thinning through which the uvea shines is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation. Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity of the sclera is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Other collagen disorders associated with it are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis (option B)
  • Polyarteritis nodosa (option A)
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

questions.text: Which of the following is a late visual field defect in open-angle glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Bjerrum scotoma (arcuate) is a late and clinically significant visual field defect.  

Progression of visual field changes seen in glaucoma:

Early non-specific changes
  • Isopter contraction
  • Baring of a blind spot: Exclusion of blind spot from the central field
Early significant changes
  • Peripheral nasal step (may be early or late)
  • Paracentral scotoma in Bjerrum's area.
  • Siedel’s  scotoma: Paracentral scotoma joins the blind spot
Late significant changes
  • Arcuate or Bjerrum scotoma
  • Ring or Double arcuate scotoma: When 2 arcuate scotomas join together
  • Roenne’s central nasal step

Advanced glaucomatous field defects
  • Tubular vision
  • No light perception: Complete visual field defect.

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: What is Glaukomflecken?
questions.solution:
Glaukomflecken is anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity and a component of Vogt's triad seen in patients after an acute angle closure glaucoma attack. 

The Vogt's triad comprises of:

  • Glaukomflecken
  • Patches of iris atrophy
  • Slightly dilated nonreactive pupil

questions.text: Which among the following would you use for the measurement of intraocular pressure in a patient with a scarred cornea?
questions.solution:
Tonopen is used for measuring intraocular pressure (IOP) in a scarred cornea.

It is a hand-held electronic contact tonometer (a modified version of the older Mackay–Marg tonometer). Besides portability, its main advantage is the ability to measure IOP reasonably accurately in eyes with distorted or edematous corneas and through a soft contact lens.

Types of tonometry:

  • Indentation tonometry- Reading depends on scleral rigidity, e.g., Schiotz tonometer  
  • Applanation tonometry- Based on the amount of force needed to flatten or applanate a known area of the cornea, Imbert–Fick principle. This is further divided into two types -
    • Fixed force: IOP is proportional to the area, e.g., Maklakov, Barraquer
    • Fixed area and variable force: IOP is proportional to force. The most reliable is Goldmann.
  • Self-measurement: Rebound
  • Non-contact type: Pulse Air, Air-Puff
  • Irregular cornea: Tonopen, MacKay–Marg

Recent tonometers:

  • Pascals tonometer (dynamic contour tonometry [DCT]): Contact; used for post-LASIK IOP measurement.
  • Reichert Ocular Response Analyzer®: Non-contact

Note: Tonography is a non-invasive technique for determining the facility of aqueous outflow.

questions.text: What is iridocorneal endothelial syndrome associated with?

choices.text: Progressive atrophy of the iris stroma
Bilateral stromal edema of the iris
Deposition of glycosaminoglycans in Descemet's membrane

questions.solution:
Progressive atrophy of iris stroma is a clinical entity of iridocorneal endothelial syndrome (ICE).

ICE syndrome is a proliferative endotheliopathy, which leads to secondary angle-closure glaucoma.

It includes three clinical entities:

  1. Progressive iris atrophy
  2. Chandler’s syndrome - corneal edema
  3. Cogan–Reese syndrome - nodules and nevus on the iris; hence, it is known as iris nevus syndrome.

questions.text: A researcher is studying mutations in the rhodopsin gene which are responsible for some forms of autosomal dominant retinitis pigmentosa. On which chromosome is this gene located?
questions.solution:
The gene for rhodopsin is located at 3q22.1

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common. Among the hereditary types, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

The presenting feature is night blindness.

Investigations:

  • Perimetry - the initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography - reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

Retinitis pigmentosa is a condition with no cure. There are drugs used to slow down the progression such as acetazolamide for concomitant cystoid macular edema. Recently, vitamin A has been recommended, although the efficacy has not been established.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the given sign seen?
questions.solution:
The image depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/enlarging dot sign, which is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR). Smokestack appearance is another pattern of fundus seen in CSR and is a characteristic sign of this condition.

Amsler grid is used for: 

  • Assess macular function and detecting maculopathy.
  • Evaluate the visual field of 10°
  • Good for follow-up in CSR

questions.text: A child presents with irritation and redness of the left eye at a primary health center. There are no previous immunization records. Examination showed a greyish-white membrane over the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva which bled on peeling. What is the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
The of a child with irritation and redness of the eye with no previous vaccination records is suggestive of a case of membranous conjunctivitis and among the given options, Corynebacterium diphtheriae is the most likely etiological agent.

Membranous conjunctivitis presents with irritation and redness of the eye and is characterized by the formation of a greyish-white membrane that bleeds on peeling. Vaccines are routinely used to prevent diphtheria infection and hence, unvaccinated status increases his susceptibility to the bacteria. Moreover, the bacteria thrive in crowded populations and poor hygienic surroundings, hence a background of low socioeconomic context, such as an orphanage, acts as a risk factor in this case.

This condition is associated with the formation of fibrinous exudates on the surface and into the substance of the conjunctival epithelium. The causes include beta-hemolytic streptococci, Streptococcus pneumonia, Haemophilus aegyptius, Corynebacterium diphtheria, and Neisseria gonorrhea

The image given below shows the eye of a patient with pseudomembranous conjunctivitis. It differs from membranous conjunctivitis in that the membrane can be easily peeled off in this condition leaving an intact underlying epithelium.

questions.text: Riddoch phenomenon is seen in lesion of?
questions.solution:
Riddoch phenomenon is seen in occipital lobe lesion.

Riddoch phenomenon:

  • Occipital lobe hemianopias are extremely congruous, having a homogeneous density with sparing of the macula.
  • Riddoch phenomenon, in which appreciation of a dim kinetic target is retained within the defective visual field with loss of appreciation of a static bright target, is typical of an occipital lesion.

questions.text: Which of the following can't be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above images shows Horner Tranta's spots which are characteristic of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).

VKC is a recurrent, bilateral, interstitial, self-limiting, allergic inflammation of the conjunctiva having a periodic seasonal incidence.

Treatment of VKC:

  • Topical anti-inflammatory therapy:
    • Topical steroids
    • Mast cell stabilzers
    • Antihistaminics
    • Topical cyclosporins
    • Tacrolimus
    • NSAIDs eye drops
  • Topical lubricating and mucolytics
  • Systemic therapy with antihistaminic and steroids
  • Treatment of large papillae:
    • Supratarsal injection of steroid
    • Cryo application
    • Surgical excision
  • Treatment of vernal keratopathy:
    • Severe shield ulcer resistant to medical therapy may need surgical debridement, superficial keratectomy and amniotic membrane transplantation to enhance re-epithelialization.

Acyclovir is given in herpes infection of the eye.

questions.text: A 26 yr old Patient came with chief complaints of blurring of vision, photophobia, and pain in eye. There was also congestion of eyes and Joint pain. All ocular complaints are unilateral. What is the investigation you won't do?
questions.solution:
The given case is likely to be a case of Uveitis. There is no reason to do FA (Fluorescein Angiography).

HLA B 27, Chest X ray, ESR are very important to rule out causes like ankylosing spondylitis, TB & sarcoidosis in a young patient which can all lead to uveitis.

Uveitis is the inflammation of uveal tissue (iris, ciliary body, choroid).

Anterior uveitis: Involvement of Iris

  • Most common symptom: Photophobia
  • Most common sign: Cells in Anterior Chamber

Intermediate Uveitis: Involvement of Pars plana and peripheral part of retina and underlying choroid.

  • Most common symptom: Floaters
  • Sign: Snowball opacities & snow banking. Seen in pars plana > ora serrata (q)
  • Most Common complication of Pars planitis 
  • Posterior Subcapsular Cataract.

Posterior uveitis: Involvement of Choroid

  • Most Common Symptom: Floaters
  • Most Common cause of visual loss: Cystoid Macular edema

Investigations:

  • Tailored approach is needed in accordance to the symptoms, recurrence, age and suspicion
  • X Ray Chest, CT Chest
  • ESR
  • TB Quantiferon
  • HLA-B27 (Ankylosing Spondylitis), HLA-B5 (Behcets), HLA-DR4 HLA-DW15 (Vogt Koyanagi Harada's disease), ANA (Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis)

Treatment:

  • Drug of choice for all type of uveitis is steroids.
  • Cycloplegics are used to break posterior synechia, relieve ciliary body spasm and ocular pain.
  • Immunosuppressant can be used in cases of steroid resistant uveitis or steroid responders.

questions.text: A child born prematurely at 31 weeks. On examination later presented with ROP both eyes shows stage 3 zone 1 ‘plus’ disease, what would be the ideal management?
questions.solution:
Any Plus Disease in ROP has to be treated with laser photocoagulation. Since the patient has ROP of both eyes, Laser photocoagulation should be done for both eyes one eye followed by the other.

Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP):

ROP Guidelines:

Which Babies To Be Screened Guidelines:

  • Birth weight less than 1500g
  • Gestational age less than 32 weeks
  • Pediatrician feels the necessity to look at the baby’s condition, like mechanical ventilation, sepsis, prolonged oxygen therapy and hemodynamic instability.

Stages:

  • Demarcation Line
  • Ridge
  • Fibrovascular Proliferation
  • Localized Tractional Retinal detachment from periphery to posterior pole
  • Total RD

Plus Disease:

  • Indicates rapid progression of the disease with vascular incompetence.
  • Two quadrants (usually six or more clock hours) of dilation and tortuosity of the posterior retinal blood vessels.

Threshold Disease in ROP:

  • Disease that has a 50% likelihood of progressing to Retinal Detachment.
  • When stage 3 ROP is present in either zone I or zone II, with at least 5 continuous or 8 total clock hours of disease, and the presence of plus disease.
  • Have to photocoagulate these babies.

ROP that requires treatment with Laser photocoagulation:

  • Zone I, any stage ROP with plus disease or
  • Zone I, stage 3, with or without plus disease
  • Zone II, stage 2 or 3 ROP, with plus disease

Not to treat, but weekly follow up:

  • Zone I, stage 1 or 2 with no plus disease or
  • Zone II, stage 3 with no plus disease

With plus disease- Always perform the Laser

ROP epidemiology:

  • LBW and LGA are two important factors that govern the development of ROP in infants. LGA more important factor than LBW.
  • WHO Vision 2020 programme targets ROP as an “avoidable disease” that requires early detection and treatment to prevent blindness and inherent costs to an individual and the community.

questions.text: Female patient having axial length of 18mm came with short stubby fingers, she has increased IOP and  subluxation of lens too. What do you suspect she may be having?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the above case is Weill marchesani syndrome.

  • Weill-Marchesani syndrome is a disorder of connective tissue with autosomal recessive mesodermal dysplasia.
  • Ocular features are spherophakia which is a small, sphere-shaped lens, which is associated with myopia which worsens over time.

There may also be forward subluxation of lens which may cause pupil block glaucoma.

Systemic features are short stature, stubby fingers and mental retardation.

Mutations in the ADAMTS10 and FBN1 genes can cause Weill-Marchesani syndrome.

Other Options:

Option B: Marfan's syndrome

It is an autosomal dominant mesodermal dysplasia. In this condition, lens is displaced upwards and temporally (bilaterally symmetrical).

Option C: Ehler danlos

  • Ocular features: are subluxation of lens and blue sclera.
  • Systemic features: include hyperextensibility of joints and loose skin with folds.

Option D: Ectopia lentis et pupillae

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder, characterised by displacement of the lens associated with slit-shaped pupil which is displaced in the opposite direction.
  • Other associations: May be cataract, glaucoma, axial myopia macrocornea, abnormal iris transillumination and retinal detachment.

Conditons causing Ectopia Lentis:

  • Congenital Ectopia Lentis- Upwards
  • Weil marchesani syndrome- Anterior dislocation
  • Homocystinuria- Inferonasal displacement
  • Marfans syndrome- Superotemporal dislocation
  • Ehler Danlos
  • Hyperlysinaemia
  • Traumatic displacement seen in couching
  • Sulfite oxidase deficiency
  • Hereditary arthro-ophthalmopathy (Stickler syndrome)
  • Consecutive displacements seen in: hypermature cataract, buphthalmos, high myopia, staphyloma, intraocular tumours and uveitis

questions.text: 100-day glaucoma is seen in
questions.solution:
Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) in central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is called 100-day glaucoma.

NVG is intractable glaucoma which results due to neovascularization involving the angle of the anterior chamber.

Neovascularization develops following retinal ischaemia as in:

  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
  • Central retinal vein occlusion
  • Sickle-cell retinopathy
  • Eales’ disease
  • Rare causes: Intraocular tumours, longstanding retinal detachment


Patients with central retinal vein occlusion are at risk for what is termed 100-day glaucoma. In CRVO, retinal ischemia of greater than 10 disc diameters indicates significant risk for NVG.

Eighty percent of patients with central retinal vein occlusion with NVG developed the disease in the first 4 months after the initial occlusion. Therefore, clinicians should follow patients every month in the first 6 months to evaluate the iris and angle.

questions.text: Zielger knife is used for which surgery?
questions.solution:
Zielger knife is used in cataract surgery.

It is used for opening the capsule of lens of eye and disrupting the lens material before aspirating it.

questions.text: Which  of the following is not a cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image is of symblepharon, where the lids become adherent with the eyeball as a result of adhesions between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva. Herpes keratitis is not a cause of this condition.

Common causes of symblepharon are:

  • Thermal or chemical burn
  • Membranous conjunctivitis
  • Injuries
  • Conjunctival ulcerations
  • Ocular pemphigus
  • Stevens-Johnson syndrome

Note:

  • Symblepharon: The adhesion of palpebral conjunctiva with bulbar conjunctiva
  • Ankyloblepharon: Adhesion of the part or whole of eyelid margins

questions.text: Blood in Anterior Chamber comes from
questions.solution:
Circulus arteriosus major is responsible for Hyphaema (blood in anterior chamber).

Hyphaema:

Causes of Hyphaema:

  • Ocular injuries
  • Postoperative
  • Herpes zoster iritis
  • Gonococcal iritis
  • Intraocular tumour
  • Spontaneous (from rubeosis iridis)

Two way irrigation and aspiration cannula can be used for aspirating hyphaema.

Blood Supply of Eye:

Cornea: Avascular

Uvea: 3 arteries are important.

  • Short post ciliary artery- Choroid
  • Long post ciliary artery-2 in number join each other near ciliary muscle with anterior ciliary arteries to form circulus arteriolar major (C A major).
  • Short anterior ciliary arteries join long posterior ciliary arteries to form C A major.
  • Branches from circulus arteriolar major go to pupillary border to form circulus arteriosus minor(C A minor).

Retina:

  • Outer four layers-choriocapillaries (RPE, rods and cones, ELM, outer nuclear layer)
  • Inner layers- Central retinal artery
  • Macula- Branches of central retinal artery + Choriocapillaries.
  • Foveola- Avascular

Optic Nerve Head:

  • Surface nerve fibre layer- From retinal arteriole.
  • Lamina cribrosa- From ciliary vessels derived from posterior ciliary artery and arterial circle of Zinn and Haller.

questions.text: The most sensitive part of the retina is _______
questions.solution:
Fovea centralis is the most sensitive part of the retina. It is the central depressed part of the macula. It is about 1.5 mm in diameter and with the lowest threshold for light and highest visual acuity, because it contains only cones.

In its centre is a shining pit called foveola. The tiny depression in the centre of foveola is called umbo which is seen as shinning foveal reflex on fundus examination.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient came with rapidly increasing power of glasses and cylindrical glasses. The topography revealed bow tie pattern. What's the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Keratoconus presents with features of rapidly changing power of the glasses.

Keratoconus:

Clinical Presentation:

  • Young male with constantly changing power of glasses with myopia & high cylinder due to myopic astigmatism.
  • Corneal topography shows Asymmetric bow tie pattern with skewed radial axis.

Morphological pattern (3 types):

  • Nipple cone (<5mm)
  • Oval cone (5-6mm)
  • Globus cone (>6mm)

Signs:

  • Munson sign
  • Enlarged corneal nerves
  • Oil droplet reflex
  • Rizutti sign (conical reflecton on nasal cornea when a penlight is shone from the temporal side)
  • Acute Hydrops (percolation of aqueous into stroma through breaks in DM)
  • Fleischer ring (at keratoconus base, a brownish ring, probably due to haemosiderin, may form in the epithelium encircling the cone)
  • Scissor reflex on retinoscopy
  • Vogt striae in slit lamp

Important associations:

  • Marfans, Down’s, EDS syndrome
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta, MVP
  • RP, Leber congenital amurosis
  • VKC, aniridia, ectopia lentis

Investigations:

  • Corneal topography
  • Pachymetry
  • Keratometry:
    • Steep cornea
    • Bow tie pattern
    • Paracentral thinning of cornea (thinnest point)

KISA index is used to classify Keratoconus.

Treatment:

  • Spectacle correction
  • Contact lens can be used include:
    • Rigid Gas Permeable
    • Rose K lenses
    • Soper lenses
  • Corneal collagen cross linking with Riboflavin
  • Intacs
  • Surgery
Surgery  Extent of involvement of cornea 

Deep Anterior Lamellar

Keratoplasty (DALK) 

 Upto 2/3rd of stroma is involved. 

Anterior Lamellar

Therapeutic

Keratoplasty(ALTK) 

 upto ½ of stroma is involved 

Penetrating

 Keratoplasty 

 When full thickness of cornea is involved as in acute hydrops with scar whole cornea is replaced

questions.text: Endophthamitis involves the inflammation of all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Endophthalmitis is defined as an inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball, i.e., uveal tissue and retina associated with pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber and posterior chamber.

Panophthalmitis is an intense purulent inflammation of the whole eyeball including the Tenon’s capsule.

questions.text: As an intern in the department of ophthalmology, you are asked regarding the indications of trabeculoplasty. In which of the following conditions would you advise this procedure?
questions.solution:
Trabeculoplasty is the procedure of choice for treatment of open-angle glaucoma. 

Indications include open angle glaucoma, pseudoexfoliative glaucoma, and pigmentory glaucoma.

In this procedure, laser spots have to be put on trabecular meshwork, that contracts and opens the channels at the rate of 50 spots on the anterior half of the trabecular meshwork over 180°. Argon Laser or Nd-Yag Laser can be used for trabeculoplasty

Complications include a transient acute rise of intraoccular pressure, which can be prevented by pretreatment with pilocarpine and/or acetazolamide. Inflammation which can be lessened by the use of topical steroids for 3-4 days.

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement about retinal detachment:

choices.text: Flashes is more specific symptom than floaters for retinal detachment
Lattices, high myopia and trauma are risk factors of retinal detachment
PDR is a cause for Tractional Retinal Detachment
It is more common in phakics than aphakics

questions.solution:
It is more common in aphakics than phakics.

Retinal Detachment:

Pathogenesis: RD is separation of neurosensory retina from retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). On retinoscopy there is Grey Reflex.

Signs & Symptoms: 

  • Curtain falling over eyes (more specific)
  • Flashes
  • Floaters (Can also appear in pars planitis, CRVO, Posterior vitreous detachment and Vitreous Hemorrhage)
  • Grey reflex on retinoscopy
  • Shaffer sign- It is pigment cells floating in anterior vitreous, behind the lens, a sign of retinal tear, that can often lead to RD. 

Risk factors:

  • Lattices 
  • Retinal tears 
  • High myopics
  • Trauma
  • Aphakia > Phakic eye

Features of Chronic RD: 

  • Watershed lines
  • Proliferative vitreo-retinopathy
  • Retinal cyst

Treatment:

  • Sealing of retinal breaks
  • Drainage of Sub Retinal Fluid
  • Scleral buckling
  • Pneumatic retinopexy
  • Pars plana vitrectomy, endolase photocoagulation, Internal tamponade
  • Treat the cause

Concept:

  • Rhegmatogenous RD is because of rhegma (holes).
  • Fibrous bands cause tractional RD, basically, tractional forces would pull the retina causing detachment.
  • Exudative RD occurs due to fluid collection beneath the retina, but there is no hole.

questions.text: Select the wrong statement about this condition:

choices.text: May be seen after valsalva maneuvere
Bleeding profile to be checked if recurrent

questions.solution:
The given image is an anterior segment photograph of subconjunctival hemorrhage which has no association with Vitreous Hemorrhage.

Subconjunctival haemorrhage:

  • Seen as normal findings seldom in 20% neonates.

  • Recurrent Subconjunctival hemorrhage may need evaluation of hypertension & bleeding profile.
  • Can be seen after intraocular surgeries.

questions.text: Werner classification is used for?
questions.solution:
Werner classification is done for assessing severity of ophthalmopathy in graves disease.

Werner classification:

  • Werner classification reflects the severity of the ophthalmopathy.
  • It is well known by the acronym of NO SPECS.
  • Each grade is further subdivided as 0-4 and a-c.

Grades of Werner classification:

Grade  Feature  Acronym 
0  No signs or symptoms  N 
1  Only signs (lid retraction)  O 
2  Soft tissue involvement (chemosis, grit)  S 
3  Proptosis (minimum <23, moderate, marked >28)  P 
4  Extraocular muscle involvement  E 
5  Corneal involvement  C 
6  Loss of Sight  S

questions.text: Anisocoria in dim light is maximally seen in
questions.solution:
Anisocoria in dim light is maximally seen in horner's syndrome.

The difference between the size of two pupils is called anisocoria. Normal size of pupil varies between 3 to 4 mm depending upon the room illumination.

Anisocoria may be physiological or pathological.

Anisocoria same in dark and bright illumination is usually physiological.

Anisocoria greater in dim illumination is suggestive of sympathetic palsy (Horner’s syndrome).

Pupillary light reflex should be tested after noting the pupil size.
Poor light reaction: defect in parasympathetic system (3rd nerve palsy, tonic pupil, anticholinergic drugs).
Normal light reaction: Horner’s syndrome

Pharmacological tests for suspected parasympathetic palsy.

  • Pupil constricts to low concentration of pilocarpine (0.125%): Adies tonic pupil.
  • Pupil constricts to usual concentration of pilocarpine (1 to 2%): 3rd nerve palsy.
  • Pupil does not constrict with pilocarpine: Mydriasis due to parasympatholytic drugs, traumatic mydriasis and fixed pupil in iritis.

Pharmacological tests for suspected sympathetic palsy include:

  • Cocaine test (2 to 4%)- Small pupil fails to dilate in Horner’s syndrome.
  • Hydroxyamphetamine test (1%)- Small pupil dilates in central and pre-ganglionic and does not dilate in post-ganglionic Horner’s syndrome.

questions.text: The number of Krause glands present in upper fornix are:
questions.solution:
Number of Krause glands in upper fornix are 42.

Krause glands:

The accessory lacrimal glands or Krause glands are microscopic groups of acini, lying below the surface of the conjunctiva between the fornix and the edge of the tarsus.

There are about

  • 42 in the upper fornix
  • 6-8 in the lower fornix

The ducts of numerous acini unite to form a larger duct, which opens into the fornix.

The moistening of the conjunctiva is done by Krause glands.

questions.text: Chalcosis is seen with
questions.solution:
Chalcosis refers to the specific changes produced by the alloy of copper in the eye.

Copper ions from the alloy are dissociated electrolytically and deposited under the membranous structures of the eye.

Clinical features:

Kayser-Fleischer ring- It is a golden brown ring which occurs due to deposition of copper at the peripheral parts of the cornea.

Sunflower cataract- It is produced by deposition of copper under the posterior capsule of the lens. It is brilliant golden green in colour and arranged like the petals of a sunflower.

Retina may show deposition of golden plaques at the posterior pole which reflect the light with a metallic sheen.

questions.text: The most common site of iris coloboma is
questions.solution:
Iris coloboma is seen most commonly in the inferonasal quadrant.

Congenital coloboma (absence of tissue) of iris, ciliary body and choroid may be seen in association or independently. It can be typical or atypical.

Typical coloboma is seen in the inferonasal quadrant and occurs due to defective closure of the embryonic fissure. It can be complete or incomplete

  • Complete coloboma extends from pupil to the optic nerve, with a sector-shaped gap occupying about one-eighth of the circumference of the retina, choroid, ciliary body, iris .
  • Incomplete coloboma may involve the iris alone, or iris and ciliary body (more common), or iris, ciliary body and part of choroid (i.e. stops short of optic nerve). 

Atypical coloboma is occasionally found in other positions. It is usually incomplete.

questions.text: A person sustained an injury to the right eye with a tennis ball, following which he developed pain. On fundus examination, a milky white macula with a red spot is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Commotio retinae, or Berlin’s edema, is the most probable diagnosis.

It occurs following a blow to the eye. It manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a considerable area of the posterior pole with a ‘cherry-red spot’ in the foveal region.

Blunt trauma to the eye produces:

  • Vossius ring - It is a circular ring of brown pigment seen on the anterior capsule. It occurs due to the striking of the contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens.
  • Rosette cataract - It is the most typical form of concussion cataract.
  • Commotio retinae (Berlin’s edema) - It manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a considerable area of the posterior pole with a "cherry-red spot" at the foveola.

It may disappear after some days or may be followed by pigmentary changes. Given below is an image of Berlin's edema.

questions.text: Features of Ocular Ischemic Syndrome include all except

choices.text: More common in elderly women than men

questions.solution:
Ocular Ischemic Syndrome is more common in males than females.

Ocular Ischemic Syndrome:

  • Vaso-occlusive pathology of retina with carotid artery/ophthalmic artery blockage with acute rise of IOP, neovascularization & sudden loss of vision.
  • Etiology- Ocular ischaemic syndrome refers to a rare condition resulting from chronic ocular hypoperfusion secondary to carotid artery stenosis.
  • It is usually unilateral (80%), affecting elderly males more commonly than females.

Risk factors:

  • Male gender,
  • Old age (60-90 years)
  • Smoking
  • Diabetes mellitus 
  • Hyperlipidaemia 

The manifestations of carotid occlusive disease include:

  • Amaurosis fugax (transient retinal ischaemic attack)
  • Retinal artery occlusion (due to embolus)
  • Transient cerebral ischaemic attacks (TIA)
  • Stroke
  • Asymmetrical diabetic retinopathy. 

Signs and symptoms:

  • Progressive loss of vision 
  • Cornea -oedema and striae.
  • Pupil may be mid dilated and poorly reacting.
  • Iris -rubeosis iridis (in 66% cases) and atrophic patches.
  • Cataract may occur as a complication in advanced cases.
  • Neovascular glaucoma is a frequent sequelae to anterior segment neovascularization. 

Fundus examination may reveal:

  • Microaneurysm
  • Dot and blot hemorrhage
  • Disc edema
  • Neovascularization
  • Dilated veins are seen, that are not tortuous
  • Retinal arterial narrowing is present.

Investigations: Confirmed by Doppler ultrasound and magnetic resonance angiography.

Treatment:

  • Treatment of the underlying cause
  • Treatment of carotid stenosis is medical (antiplatelet therapy, oral anticoagulants) and surgical (carotid endarterectomy).

questions.text: Recurrent corneal erosion is seen in :
questions.solution:
Recurrent corneal erosions (recurrent keractalgia) is seen in corneal dystrophy.

Patient usually gets recurrent attacks of acute pain and lacrimation with varying extent of corneal haziness. This occurs due to abnormally loose attachment of epithelium to the underlying Bowman’s membrane.

The frequent causes are:

  • Post traumatic non dystrophic erosion without primary basement membrane abnormality is the most common cause
  • Epithelial basement membrane corneal dystrophy (cogan's microcytic dystrophy, map-dot finger print dystrophy)
  • Diabetes mellitus

Treatment:

Loosely attached epithelium should be removed by debridement and ‘pad and bandage’ applied for 48 hours, so that firm healing is established.

questions.text: Angioid streaks in the eyes are seen in:
questions.solution:
Angioid streaks are associated with Pseudoxanthoma elasticum.

Angioid streaks are dark brown streaks which may be mistaken for blood vessels are sometimes seen ophthalmoscopically.

They are usually situated near the disc at a deeper level than the retinal vessels, and are very irregular in contour.

They are due to changes in the elastic tissue of Bruch's membrane, and are frequently associated with more widespread degeneration of the elastic tissue of the skin pseudoxanthoma elasticum.

Other associations with angioid streaks:

  • Paget disease of bone
  • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
  • Sickle cell disease

questions.text: Not true about malignant glaucoma:

choices.text: Anterior Chamber flat in centre than in periphery
Nd Yag hyaloidotomy can be attempted

questions.solution:
Pilocarpine is contraindicated for medical management of malignant glaucoma.

Malignant glaucoma:

  • Also called Cilliary Block glaucoma and Aqueous Misdirection Syndrome.
  • It is rare complication seen Post Trabeculectomy , iridotomy, yag capsulotomy or any intra-ocular surgery.

Features:

  • Anterior chamber is flat more in centre than in periphery (shallow AC)
  • Acute rise of IOP
  • Negative Siedel’s test
  • Ciliary body malrotation to posterior segment causing aqueous misdirection posteriorly

Treatment:

  • Atropine is used as medical management
  • Nd Yag Hyaloidotomy
  • Vitrectomy
  • Aqueous suppressants and hyperosmotics may be used

Contraindications of pilocarpine:

  • Inflammatory glaucoma
  • Malignant glaucoma 
  • Allergy to pilocarpine

questions.text: Band shaped keratopathy is seen in ?’
questions.solution:
Vitamin D poisoning presents with band shaped keratopathy

Band shaped keratopathy:

It is seen in

  • Blind shrunken eyes
  • Children suffering from Still disease
  • Aphakic eyes which have undergone vitrectomy with silicone oil
  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Vitamin D poisoning
  • Sarcoidosis

Features:

  • A whitish band appears in the interpalpebral area, commencing at the inner and outer sides and progressing until it forms a continuous band across the cornea, interspersed with round 'holes' or cleaves in the band itself.(in the fig)
  • Close to the limbus, however, the cornea is generally relatively clear, as in so many degenerative conditions, probably owing to the better nutrition close to the blood vessels.
  • The condition is due to hyaline infiltration of the superficial parts of the stroma, followed by the deposition of calcareous salts.

Treatment:

  • Improvement of vision may be obtained by scraping off the opacity, which is usually calcareous and quite superficial, or dissolving it with the sodium salt of ethylenediamine tetra-acetic acid (sodium edetate).
  • It can also be removed with the excimer laser (phototherapeutic keratectomy).

Fig:  Band Shaped keratopathy

questions.text: Snow banking is seen in?
questions.solution:
Snow banking is a feature of pars planitis

Pars planitis:

  • Intermediate uveitis, also known as chronic posterior cyclitis or pars planitis.
  • It affects the pars plana of the ciliary body and the periphery of the choroid.
  • It occurs particularly in children and young adults.
  • Females are more commonly affected than males.
  • The onset is insidious.
  • Both eyes are affected in 80% of cases.

Symptoms:

  • Floaters
  • Deterioration of vision

Signs:

  • Minimal aqueous flare
  • Occasional keratic precipitates (sometimes termed a 'spill-over' anterior uveitis)
  • Anterior vitritis
  • Snow banking: White snowball- like exudates near the ora serrata, coalescent exudates giving the appearance of a 'snowbank' and mild peripheral periphlebitis
  • Macular oedema, papillitis or disc oedema.

Treatment:

  • Self limiting usually with a good prognosis
  • Corticosteroids
  • Immunosuppressants

questions.text: Duochrome test is used

choices.text: To measure near add for presbyopia

questions.solution:
Duochrome test:

The Duochrome test helps in refining the cylinder power and axis for spherical correction.

Principle:

  • Duochrome test is based on the principle of chromatic aberration.
  • Duochrome test does refining of spherical power of glasses.

Procedure:

  • In Duochrome test- We put Red glass in front of right eye. Green glass in front of left eye.
  • Normally, Green rays are focused slightly anterior, Red rays are focused slightly posterior to retina.
  • So to an emmetropic eye they look equally bright, that should be our aim.
  • We ask the patient, which is clearer “Red or Green?”. If he says red is clearer this means glasses we have given is more myopic. We adjust till it becomes equal, both red and green.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding color blindness?

choices.text: Optic nerve head is blue blind
Ganglion cells are responsible for color vision processing
Tritanopia refers to defective appreciation of blue color

questions.solution:
Color blindness:

  • More common in males than in female because the genes that produce photopigments are carried on the X chromosome.
  • Fovea is blue blind.
  • Ganglion cells are the cells mainly responsible for color vision processing.
  • Human eyes are most sensitive to green colour.

Tests: 

  • Nagel’s Anomaloscope
  • The Lantern test
  • Ishihara’s test
  • Farnsworth-Munsell 100 hue test.
  • Holmgren’s wools test
  • City university colour vision test.

Terms:

  • Tritanomalous: Blue
  • Deuteranomalous: Green
  • Protanomalous: Red

Anomalous- Defective appreciation of color

Anopia- Total or complete defect

Difference b/w Tritanomalous and Tritanopia: Blue Cones are the culprit. If the patient is not able to identify the blue color completely then it is triatnopia, if there is defective differentiation and he is seeing it in varying shades of yellow green its tritanomalous.

In option D tritanopia is said to be defective appreciation of blue colour, but actually it is tritanomalous that is the defective appreciation of blue colour, whereas tritanopia is the inability to identify blue colour completely.

Types of Cones:

  • S- Short wavelength: Blue
  • M- Medium wavelength: Green
  • L- Long wavelength: Red
